awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to William Chen is "Arithmetic and geometric aspects of noncongruence subgroups of SL(2,Z)." The host institution for the fellowship is McGill University, and the sponsoring scientist is Henri Darmon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A Riemann surface is a surface equipped with a complex structure, which intuitively allows one to measure angles between two intersecting lines on the surface. A modular curve is a Riemann surface obtained as the quotient of the upper half plane by a finite index subgroup of SL(2,Z). The curve is congruence if the subgroup is a congruence subgroup (i.e., the subgroup can be described by imposing congruence conditions on the coefficients of the matrices), and noncongruence otherwise. The theory of congruence modular curves is extremely rich, and despite its geometric nature, has led to breakthroughs in number theory such as the modularity theorem and the consequent proof of Fermat's Last Theorem. Noncongruence modular curves on the other hand are far less well understood. The project's main purpose was to investigate the arithmetic and geometric properties of noncongruence modular curves, using the congruence case to inspire questions and calibrate expectations.

A main outcome of the project is a new result on a certain family of noncongruence modular curves. The paper is to appear in Annals of Mathematics, titled "Nonabelian level structures, Nielsen equivalence, and Markoff triples". This result has implications in group theory, algebraic geometry, and number theory, each interesting in their own right.

In terms of group theory, the result can be viewed as a statement about Nielsen equivalence classes of generating pairs of the groups SL(2,p) for varying primes p. If (a,b) is a generating pair of SL(2,p) such that the commutator [a,b] = a*b*a^-1*b^-1 has trace -2, then the result shows that any other such generating pair can be obtained from (a,b) by a sequence of elementary Nielsen moves (these are moves of the form (x,y) --> (y,x^-1) or (x,y) --> (x,xy)). Such results have applications to the theory of expander graphs, which in turn have a number of applications in computer science and cryptography. This version resolves a special case of the "Q-classification conjecture" of McCullough and Wanderley.

In terms of algebraic geometry, the result shows that an infinite family of "Hurwitz" moduli spaces with fixed genus of the base curve and fixed ramification profile but varying Galois group is connected. Specifically, it says that for large enough primes p, the "Hurwitz" moduli space of SL(2,p)-Galois covers of elliptic curves only branched above the origin with ramification index 2p is connected. While many connectedness results for Huwitz spaces are known when the Galois group is fixed but the ramification profile or base curve genus varies, connectedness results for Hurwitz spaces for varying nonsolvable Galois groups are quite rare, and this is one of the first results of the type. This result is key to unlocking a number of other results about this family of noncongruence modular curves. For example, using the connectedness result, we are able to calculate the genus of the curves in this family, and prove a noncongruence analog of Rademacher's conjecture on congruence modular curves.

In terms of number theory, the question essentially resolves a conjecture of Baragar, Bourgain, Gamburd, and Sarnak from 1991 and 2016, and answers a question of Frobenius from 1913. A Markoff triple is a triple of integers (x,y,z) satisfying the Markoff equation x^2+y^2+z^2-3xyz = 0. The result says that the set of Markoff triples satisfies strong approximation, which is to say that every mod p solution of the Markoff equation is obtained from an integer solution by reduction mod p. This version of the result is interesting due to the ubiquity of Markoff numbers in many areas of mathematics, ranging from Diophantine approximation to hyperbolic geometry, representation theory, and the derived categories of varieties. It is also interesting because the Markoff equation belongs to a class of affine hypersurfaces whose Diophantine (i.e. number-theoretic) properties are extremely subtle.

In addition to the above results, the project also produced a paper where we describe how to construct an infinite family of covers of the projective line in characteristic p with 3 branch points, controlled monodromy group, and controlled tame ramification. This result is in the spirit of a tame Abhyankar's conjecture, which roughly seeks to quantify the difference between covers of the projective line in characteristic 0 vs characteristic p. This paper has been published in Algebra and Number Theory, under the title "Tamely ramified covres of the projective line with alternating and symmetric monodromy".

Finally, the project has also led to the discovery of infinitely many finite simple characteristic quotients of the free group of rank 2, together with additional results on the structure of Nielsen equivalence classes of generating pairs of metabelian groups.
